PGA.description: Peak Ground Acceleration (PGA), the maximum expected ground acceleration at the site due to earthquake shaking, reflecting short-period seismic demand that strongly affects stiff structures and foundations.

SS.description: The mapped short-period spectral acceleration at the site before site soil effects are applied, representing seismic demand on short-period structural components.

S1.description: The mapped 1.0-second spectral acceleration at the site before site soil effects are applied, representing seismic demand on longer-period structural systems.

SMS.description: The site-adjusted short-period spectral acceleration that accounts for local soil amplification or attenuation of seismic ground motions.

SDS.description: The design-level short-period spectral acceleration used directly in seismic design, reflecting reduced demand consistent with code-defined performance objectives.

SDCS.description: The seismic design category that classifies overall seismic risk at the site and governs required detailing, analysis rigor, and design provisions.

code_map.A: Code 'A' represents sites with very low seismic hazard, where minimal or no seismic detailing is required, allowing for simplified structural design and reduced construction costs.
code_map.B: Code 'B' indicates low seismic hazard conditions, necessitating limited seismic design provisions to ensure basic structural integrity during minor seismic events, balancing safety and cost-effectiveness.
code_map.C: Code 'C' applies to moderate seismic hazard areas, where seismic forces significantly influence design, requiring ductile detailing to enhance structural resilience against potential seismic activity.
code_map.D: Code 'D' is assigned to high seismic hazard zones, demanding substantial seismic design forces and ductile detailing to accommodate inelastic behavior and ensure structural safety during strong earthquakes.
code_map.E: Code 'E' pertains to very high seismic hazard conditions, necessitating the most stringent design and detailing to withstand extreme ground motions and protect structural integrity during severe seismic events.
code_map.F: Code 'F' is used for site-specific extreme seismic hazards, requiring specialized analysis and design beyond standard procedures to address unique seismic challenges and ensure structural safety.

PGAM.description: The mapped peak ground acceleration associated with maximum considered earthquake conditions prior to any site-specific adjustments.

FPGA.description: The peak ground acceleration adjusted for local site conditions, representing the ground motion intensity expected to be experienced at the bridge location.
